data.name: Four Color Theorem for Cylindrical Projection
data.description:
### Beta Note: * I think all test answers are correct. I checked many scenarios. But there could be something missing. If you find errors, please inform me of them. * Suggestions for fixed tests are welcome. Also looking for faster algrithms, esp. map gen; * Added JS translation. JS runs much faster than python. So the more random tests in JS cover special cases better. (24Dec2020) * Corrected an error in my algrithm, which gave wrong answer 3 instead of 4 in some special cases; * Add `~` as water into the map. It reduced map size needed for special graphs; To avoid maintaining two languages, I deleted python for now, and will add back when everything becomes stable. --- # Four Color Theorem In mathematics, the four color theorem, or the four color map theorem, states that, given any separation of a plane into contiguous regions, producing a figure called a map, no more than four colors are required to color the regions of the map so that no two adjacent regions have the same color. Adjacent means that two regions share a common boundary curve segment, not merely a corner where three or more regions meet. It was the first major theorem to be proved using a computer.
Fig. 1: A four-coloring of a map of the states of the United States (ignoring lakes).
While every planar map can be colored with four colors, it is NP-complete in complexity to decide whether an arbitrary planar map can be colored with just three colors.[1] For some cases, even three colors are not required, for example two colors are enough to distinguish the squares on a chessboard. --- # Task Find the minimum amount of colors needed to fill a map with no neighboring territories having the same color. ### Input The test map will be inputed as a string. For example the map below has 9 different territories. It needs 3 colors to seperate them. Usually there is more than one way to color a map. A possible color pattern for the map below is: * Color 1: A, C, D, H * Color 2: B, b, E * Color 3: F, G ```python """ AABBCC AABBCC bbDDEF bbDDGH """ ``` #### Input Notes: - The territory names are case sensitive, B and b are different territories; - Territories are considered adjacent only if they share an edge, A is adjacent to B, but Not D; - One territory is always connected, there are no discrete islands; - Chars of ASCII 33~126 will be used (see...no 32) - Inputs are always rectangular, ignore tailing spaces if any ### Output The output should be an `int`. --- Warriors who solve this kata need think big. The map is not for a county, or a city. They are all maps of planets. There are several projection ways to map a sphere to a flat rectangular. The approach we use here is the cylindrical projection. ***So the left and right edges of the map are connected.*** Since cylindrical projection brings big distortions on two polar areas. We did not include polar areas in the map. ***Don't worry about the top and bottom edges of the map. They connect to nothing.*** Use the above input string as the example again. A and C are adjacent to each other; same to b, F and H. But G and b are not connected; they won't meet at the south pole.
Fig. 2: A Miller cylindrical projection maps the globe onto a cylinder.
More about the tests: * There are about 50 fixed tests and 1000 random tests. Fixed tests are not necessarily easier, they include some special cases. Please don't hard code them; * Maps can be big. If we call the sample input above a 6x4 = 24 pixel map, a large map in random tests could have 2,500 pixels; * All tests will have no more than 90 territories; * There may be lakes, rivers, seas or oceans which need a certain color, i.e. blue; so **ignore water areas during coloring; water is represented by `~`;** water's blue should not be counted into your result; * Some planets have one territory only; some planets do not have lands, just water surface only; * A planet that was destroyed by the Death Star doesn't have any territories. In this case, the input will be an empty string. * The oldie but goodie: you will find more in sample tests. Here are more examples: ``` Sample input strings: 1) "ABCD" 2) "ABC" 3) "AAA\nDBC\nDBC" 4) "AAAA\nACCA\nDBCA" 5) "ABAA\nABCA\nDBCA" 6) "~A~\n~~~\n~C~" ``` 1. A is adjacent to B; B is adjacent to C; C is adjacent to D; while in the end D is adjacent to A since is a cylindrical projection; in this case, two colors are enough to distinguish all the territories. Your code should return `2`; 1. It's the first case without D. Now A is adjacent to B and C. Two color are not enough. Your code should return `3`; 1. C is touching D, because it's a circle. Your code should return `4`; 1. B is not adjacent to A anymore, while A extended between C and D. In this case, two colors is enough to distinguish them. Your code should return `2`; 1. While B touches A again, your code should return `3` for this input. However, B cuts thru A. Should all territories be connected to itself? Remember, the input represents a cylindric map not a rectangular map. If we wrap the input around a cylinder, A becomes one connected territory. So this input is valid. (BTW, the "A"s on the right and "A"s on the left should have a same color.) 1. Water, i.e. `~`, should be ignored; Though there are two islands, they can have a same color, while your code should return `1` not `2`;
Fig. 3: The minimum amount of colors needed to fill a map
Parsing a map to graph is not what this Kata wants to test. Cylindrical projection and water will introduce more special cases in graphs. --- [1] Dailey, D. P. (1980), "Uniqueness of colorability and colorability of planar 4-regular graphs are NP-complete", Discrete Mathematics, 30 (3): 289â€“293

Not to reduce the Kata's fun and challenges, I put more hints [HERE](https://github.com/GaryDoooo/public_codewar_info/blob/main/hint/4color.md), in case you need it.
